awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Compact Binary Formation with the First Gravitational Wave Detections
awd_abstract_narration:
The formation and evolution of binaries of compact astrophysical objects (black holes and neutron stars) is an important and challenging problem in astrophysics. Observational data of such systems comes from radio telescope detections of binaries with at least one pulsating neutron star, or pulsar, and from gravitational-wave observations of the final few seconds to minutes of the lives of the binary, when they inspiral and merge.  A research collaboration between Johns Hopkins University and Pennsylvania State University will use gravitational-wave observations to explore astrophysical models of compact binaries, using statistical inference and machine learning.  Among the specific scientific topics to be addressed are the details of how compact binaries form, the use of compact binary mergers to measure distances to sources far off in the universe, and understanding the state of matter in the dense cores of neutron stars.  The phenomenal discoveries by the gravitational-wave detectors have received a great deal of attention from the press and in social media. Black holes, neutron stars and gravitational waves are topics of great interest to the public, and have the potential to attract students in middle and high schools to STEM subjects who would have otherwise chosen other alternatives.  The researchers will use the current surge of interest in these areas to inform middle and high students of the excitement of research and discovery in the forefront of physics. 

The proposed research will shed light on evolutionary models of compact binaries using a catalog of binary merger events observed by the LIGO and Virgo gravitational-wave detectors. More specifically, the goal of the project is to discriminate between competing evolutionary models of compact binaries (dynamical interactions in clusters, evolution of isolated binaries, and primordial origin of binary black holes) from the measured distributions of masses, spins and other properties of compact object mergers. This study will help produce a map from the astrophysical models to the bulk properties of the systems measured from gravitational wave observations. Such maps, in combination with Bayesian inference and machine learning, will be used to gain a deeper understanding of the astrophysics of compact object binaries. The investigators will use compact binaries as accurate measures of distance to obtain peculiar velocities of galaxies and clusters, 3-d mapping of galaxies, and to characterize the gas, stellar and dark matter content of galaxies, comparing the results with other approaches. Gravitational wave observations are key to multi-messenger astronomy, which will help address the origin questions, such as how and when black holes formed and how they evolved, what constitutes the expansion history of the Universe, and what is the state of matter in dense cores of neutron stars. This project advances the goals of the NSF Windows on the Universe Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The groundbreaking discovery of gravitational waves by the American Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) in 2015 marked a pivotal moment in scientific history, opening new vistas for understanding the Universe.  Subsequent detections by LIGO and the European Virgo have unveiled insights into coalescing binaries of neutron stars and black holes, prompting plans for even more sensitive detectors like the US Cosmic Explorer (CE) and European Einstein Telescope (ET), which will observe these systems from epochs when the first stars after the Big Bang began to appear in the Universe.

 

Neutron stars and black holes are end states in the evolution of massive progenitor stars. The latter are produced if the progenitor star is 8-20 solar masses, more massive progenitors result in the formation of black holes. Stars lose most of their mass in winds and supernova explosions and the remnant neutron stars are only 1-3 solar masses, while black holes can be a few solar masses to about 60 solar masses.

 

One of the outstanding problems in astrophysics is the formation and evolution of binaries consisting of black holes and neutron stars: their merger rate, the mass and spin distributions of their companions and evolution of these as a function of cosmological redshift. LIGO-Virgo observations of 100 binaries at low redshifts have provided us with mass distributions of black holes and neutron stars and their merger rates, although with large uncertainties. Aided with this information, and assuming that merger rate is proportional to the star formation rate as a function of redshift, we computed the cosmological merger rates of these systems in the Universe, which in turn allowed us to predict that Cosmic Explorer and Einstein Telescope will observe about a million merger signals each year.  Current data sets cannot discriminate between different models, which include black hole binaries that form in isolation, in globular or dense star clusters, at galactic centers, or in the primordial Universe.  CE and ET observations will provide a treasure trove of data for studying astrophysical models of coalescing binaries.

 

Some of the challenges posed by current observations are the features in the mass spectrum, events with individual black hole masses larger than 60 solar masses and mass ratios of binary companions as large as ten, none of which can be explained by current astrophysical models. We developed a simple model of hierarchical mergers that allowed us to address all of these questions. The model begins with a population of black holes whose initial mass is distributed over a narrow range but builds up larger black holes via hierarchical mergers. The model can predict populations that will be observed by CE and ET.

 

Our computations revealed a new data analysis challenge posed by the vast number of binary neutron star mergers, some lasting for hours as they sweep through the sensitivity window of CE and ET. Consequently, hundreds of overlapping signals will be present at any time. Our analysis shows that although detecting overlapping signals will not be a problem, unbiased estimation of parameters and subtracting them from the data to identify other signals could be an issue that must be addressed with new regression algorithms. Furthermore, we estimated the impact of overlapping signals in broadening the parameter estimation of a GW170817-like event, finding that masses, spins, and distance are biased in about half of the events under realistic circumstances. The sky localization of such events, while still precise, can be biased in up to 80% of the cases, potentially posing a problem in follow-up searches for electromagnetic counterparts.

 

Neutron stars are about 50% more massive than the sun but they pack all of that mass in a radius of about 10 km. Consequently, neutron stars have the greatest densities anywhere in the Universe, each cubic cm containing billions of tons of nuclear matter. Understanding the equation-of-state of dense neutron star matter is a principal goal of nuclear physics. Gravitational-wave observations provide an independent probe of the properties of bulk matter in neutron star cores. We quantified the accuracy with which LIGO-Virgo, their imminent upgrades and future detectors like CE and ET will progressively pin down the equation of state of dense matter. Some models of nuclear physics predict that quarks confined in neutrons in ordinary matter could be squeezed out at supra nuclear densities in a process called the quantum chromodynamic phase transition. We also explored the sensitivity needed to observe such phase transitions, concluding that next generation observatories would be necessary to identify such phenomena. 

 

In essence, this comprehensive exploration of gravitational wave astronomy not only reflects on past achievements but also outlines the exciting prospects and challenges that lie ahead, promising to deepen our understanding of the cosmos.
